claim:
The institutional review board of the Illinois College of Optometry approved the study protocol and consent information.Survey Administration
The subjects received an email with consent information and a link to the multiple choice, 4-question survey that was hosted by Survey Monkey (Fig. 1).
title: Figure 1.
caption: Survey tool with consent verbiage for 2008 meeting abstracts. The year was changed in the survey tools for 2006 and 2007 meeting abstracts.

claim: For the subjects' academic background, the majority of the respondents (82%, 55/67) were doctors of chiropractic (Fig. 2).
title: Figure 2.
caption: Academic background of authors responding to surveys.

claim: For the professional situation, most of the subjects were clinical faculty members (52%, 34/65), followed by basic science faculty members, including those in research departments (34%, 22/65; Fig. 3).
title: Figure 3.
caption: Professional situation/occupation of survey respondents.

Professional situation/occupation of survey respondents.Only 66% (44/67) of the abstracts were reported as never being submitted for publication (Fig. 4), while 4% (3/67) had a manuscript submitted and rejected.
title: Figure 4.
caption: Status of abstract with regard to publication.

claim: Overall, the self-reported barriers to publication for those that had not submitted a manuscript for publication (n = 44) were varied, with publishing as a low priority named the most frequent barrier, followed by inadequate time (Fig. 5).
title: Figure 5.
caption: Barriers to publication. Time: not enough time to prepare the paper for manuscript. Priority: pursuit of publication was a low priority. Preliminary: presentation was preliminary work for a larger ongoing study. Co-author: difficulty with co-authors. Another: responsibility of writing the manuscript belonged to someone else. Methods: a low likelihood that a journal would accept it for publication because of methodological limitations of the work. No release: no release time was granted to work on the manuscript. Case study: the presentation was a case study and rules of the group supporting the study forbid publication of case studies. Diff version: a different version of the data were published. Similar: other studies with similar findings were already published. Unimportant: the results were not important enough. Negative stats: the statistical analysis was not positive. Plan to submit: plan to submit for publication.
